description: Volta bridges health tech, insurtech, and edtech, leveraging AI and data intelligence to automate regulated insurance and healthcare processes for colleges and universities.
problem_statement:
- Our flagship service addresses a critical compliance requirement for universities. Educational institutions mandate health insurance coverage for their student populations—sometimes due to state regulations (e.g., Massachusetts) and invariably as a risk mitigation, reputation protecting measure. Consider a student who fractures their leg during an intramural game—no matter how comprehensive a university’s health center is, that student will likely need hospital care. If the student lacks adequate insurance, the situation becomes a major headache for the student and university, leading to potential reputational damage, legal liability from parents, retention risks due to medical debt, and even financial liability for hospitals covering uninsured students.Since the Affordable Care Act (ACA), the majority of students—up to 90% in some cases—are covered under their parents’ insurance. Thus, these students can waive out of the university-sponsored health insurance plan (SHIP), but the waiver process is complex. Schools impose specific requirements such as deductible limits, HMO vs. PPO preferences, and restrictions on out-of-state plans, making verification of an entire student body a logistical nightmare.
    - *Universities*
        - Educational institutions face two options for insurance verification: building an in-house verification team or outsourcing to brokerage firms. While some institutions with substantial resources handle this internally (e.g., Yale, Emory), most—even including prestigious institutions like Stanford and Brown—outsource this function at significant expense. Volta reduces these costs by millions of dollars annually. (See below for calculus).
    - *Brokers*
        - Brokerage firms provide two primary services to universities: procurement of official SHIP plan (generating a 5% commission on premium value) and administration of enrollment/waiver processes of said plan (increasing commissions to 15%). Using two New York institutions as examples, NYU's $80 million yearly premium and Columbia's $125 million yearly premium generate $8 million and $12.5 million respectively in commissions for waiver and enrollment administration alone. By partnering with Volta, brokers maintain their commission structure while outsourcing the labor-intensive verification process to us at a fraction of the cost, substantially increasing their profit margins.
    - Payers
        - Insurance providers face considerable challenges in the current ecosystem. Brokers' annual renegotiation practices create unpredictable revenue streams and prevent insurers from recouping implementation costs. Volta enables insurers to bypass brokerage intermediaries by directly addressing universities' most significant pain point—the waiver and enrollment process. While plan selection is relatively straightforward for institutions, it is the managing of verification for thousands of students and dependents presents considerable operational challenges that our platform efficiently resolves.
- Insurance Billing
    - University health centers function as de facto clinics, offering essential medical services to students. Yet, unlike traditional healthcare providers, they *do not bill third party insurance*. Instead, universities absorb these healthcare costs as operational expenses. Volta changes this dynamic. We introduce the capability to bill insurance providers for eligible services, enabling health centers to achieve financial sustainability without the added burden of figuring out coding, billing, etc. This approach allows institutions to, at minimum, break even on health center operations and potentially generate revenue that can offset student health fees, making healthcare more accessible and sustainable for students.

Our core offerings automate previously manual compliance processes in addition to turning historical cost drivers into revenue generating centers.

product_differentiation.justification:
Competitors: Brokerage firms typically offer universities two core services: securing the official Student Health Insurance Plan (SHIP), which yields them a 5% commission on the plan’s total premium, and managing the enrollment and waiver process, which can boost their commission to 15%. Take, for example, two major New York institutions—NYU and Columbia. With annual SHIP premiums of $80 million and $125 million respectively, these firms earn $8 million and $12.5 million solely from administering waivers and enrollments. Yet despite these substantial fees, brokers have not only inflated costs across the industry but also consistently underperformed, frequently failing to capture the full potential premium value for their clients.
In-market since: In January 2024, we launched a pilot program with Ohio State University and have since worked with Venbrook Brokerage, Emory, and University of Mount Saint Vincent.

Despite significant constraints—no marketing budget, no dedicated sales team, and a CEO transitioning to full-time leadership in June 2024 after completing an MBA—Volta has demonstrated remarkable growth potential. This momentum signals a promising trajectory as the venture solidifies its strategic foundation.
Customers: https://volta.docsend.com/v/kkwtb/salesnpipeline
Pricing: 3 paying customers. We operate under a bifurcated business model designed to align closely with the value we deliver to institutions.

The first component is commission-based: we earn a 5% commission on the total premium of each health plan. Additionally, we charge a 10% commission on any premiums generated above the institution’s historical enrollment baseline—essentially incentivizing and rewarding increased student engagement and plan adoption.

The second part of our model is SaaS-based. We charge a recurring software fee for access to our suite of non-insurance features, which includes personalized care navigation, mental health integrations, and digital tools that streamline administrative workflows.

strategic_fit.justification: Aligned with SV’s thesis around digital transformation and workforce innovation.

red_flags:
We’re building in a space — student health and wellness — that has historically been underserved by technology, so there’s an educational component to our outreach. We’re not just selling a solution; we’re often helping stakeholders reimagine what’s possible.

Additionally, like many early-stage companies, we’re balancing limited resources while trying to move quickly — expanding our product, onboarding new partners, and scaling implementation without compromising quality.

As we scale Volta, there are a few areas where we’d benefit from deeper knowledge and support. First, we’re looking to strengthen our channel partnerships — we’ve seen early interest from brokers, carriers and strategic distributors, but the payer space is relationship based and as such continually evolving one's network is critical.

We’re also looking to expand our network within large healthcare organizations and benefits platforms that serve the higher ed markets. While we’ve made strong inroads with universities, connecting more directly with decision-makers at larger distribution channels would accelerate our growth.

founder_impact_assessment:
One of the most important learnings we had early in building Volta was realizing that what we started with was a “nice-to-have.” Our initial product resonated with students, but it didn’t solve a core pain point for the stakeholders who controlled the budgets. The turning point came when we stepped back and started following the money — mapping out who was spending, who was making decisions, and where the real friction existed. That led us to uncover a part of the student health ecosystem that was deeply fragmented, outdated, and full of inefficiencies no one had solved for.

That insight pushed us to pivot from a student-facing wellness app to a platform that directly reduces administrative burden, integrates with existing systems, and helps schools meet growing compliance, engagement, and care coordination demands.

gtm_support_potential.justification:
This program feels like a rare opportunity for a startup like Volta to sharpen our go-to-market strategy and build meaningful relationships with the right people. The combination of targeted advice from experienced industry leaders, real-time feedback from corporate decision-makers, and access to a proven channel partnership playbook is incredibly compelling. We’re especially excited about the chance to pitch to innovation councils at large distributors — that kind of exposure and feedback could be a game-changer for us at this stage.

The opportunity to learn directly from experts through focused webinars, prep sessions, and one-on-one advisory meetings would help us avoid common pitfalls and scale smarter. And the long-term value of joining a strong alumni network and tapping into vetted resources and tools is something we don’t take lightly. We’re looking for partners who get what we’re building — and this program looks like it was built for companies like ours.
